nodes.bodyText: have you got final configured in your IDE? I think final added everywhere really makes the code heavy to read. I think it's not worth it

this is an interesting solution in general. But for ManagaCaseAssignment won't work I think. I've been recently told that the only IDAM role the client has is caseworker-caa and she needs to see all the existing case types. In this case this will return an empty list
temporary: why we getting only the field of type label here?

lots of code emerging more and more often to deal with path manipulation. 2 examples in this class, here another:

  
    
      ccd-data-store-api/src/main/java/uk/gov/hmcts/ccd/domain/model/definition/SearchResultField.java
    
    
         Line 61
      in
      0fc75ab
    
    
    
    

        
          
           return Arrays.stream(this.caseFieldPath.trim().split("\\.")).collect(Collectors.toList());

temporary: does this mean every time a service introduces a new use case we need to do a new release of Data Store?
we are trying to follow the convention that all internal api result objects are denoted by View. Well probably need to do some renaming of the various classes. Let's discuss that separately

temporary: I would not model this as an operation with an execute method. Because by convention in Data Store Operation classes correspond to business operations like create case, view case. Even thought I can see we are introducing them for other things recently. This could just be a Service maybe?
was thinking it might prove useful to also add the use case here. For standard requests it's going to have value null
not needed. Let's removed it please

I know other v2 apis have versioned custom vendor types, but I'd like to follow HMCTS guidelines from now on which says API versioning should be avoided. We can then use a generic media type application/json here. See:
https://tools.hmcts.net/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1392411337#RDM-8325:InternalSearchAPI-3.1-Vendor-SpecificMediaTypes

temporary: now that we are making ctid optional in the external search API to allow searching on all existing case types, is there any benefit in doing this? maybe yes since we have to know anyway for access control the actual case types a user can access. In that case, probably this is something that should be done by the external search API itself.

I wouldn't introduce a concept of Default use case. It's a bit misleading we don't really have a default use case. If use case is not passed then is missing.
Can't we just check whether the string is empty or null?
use case is a concept of the internal API only. It should not appear here. Better to keep in this common class only some minimal code needed for sure by both.

potential regression risk here ⚠️ . We have changed the external API. We introduced:
buildCaseTypeIds(caseTypeIds)
on the external API which definitely would require regression testing.
in the code base methods we don't really mention external vs internal. I'd keep it agnostic as simply execute.
I would keep the code method and classes agnostic to the external vs internal classification

some elements are not suitable for the external API. for example the concept of use case, and the adding of the default sorting. If we want to keep this common class shared between the external and internal api, then let's keep only the things strictly in common

nodes.bodyText: my IDE flag this as unused. Can we remove?

I like the idea of having common code in ElasticsearchQueryHelper but because we are moving everything in there the controllers are almost empty and ElasticsearchQueryHelper is quite complex. We could improve things by moving the code in prepareRequest back to the controllers. And leave the utility methods common to both in ElasticsearchQueryHelper. I prefer to see in the controller method itself the steps it's taking.

minor: if we moved this code inside the CaseSearchOperation.execute we could have the external search API be completely responsible to create the CrossCaseTypeSearchRequest. We just delegate to the external. What do you think? too much stuff to move around?
My point is that I would rather have the internal delegate stuff as much as possible to the external.

I would strongly suggest we introduce a separated class that deals only with manipulation of the JSON response. Nothing else.
For example a ElasticSearchRequest class. With methods like:
new ElasticSearchRequest(jsonRequest)
esr.toJson()
esr.isSorted()
esr.addSorting(fields)
For now we can use it here only and then pass down to the external API the json request by calling .toJson(). So we don't have to change much code

this class is too big, because is doing too many unrelated things. Like applying sorting, validation, Json manipulation. We need to apply separation of concerns and move some stuff out to other helper classes. Some thing can be moved back to the controller.
minor: probably we could have considered removing the use case so we cache the whole SearchCasesResultFields tab to decrease the network calls when requesting different use cases

can we find a better name? maybe getNestedCaseFieldByPath?
can you also add a little javadoc with description here and on the other methods too please
minor: sorry Dan I changed my mind only if it's not a big change can we remove use case? I should have applied YAGNI

I find it very confusing that once there results are already returned by the searchQueryOperation then we are then calling it again during the
generation of the final response
I wouldn't call the whole operation. I think we can simplify things by just getting it from the DefRepo? The external API will take care of access control. Important thing that we test this.
how come we are building new hashmaps?

not sure I understand why we are getting the fields of type label for here. Furthermore, shall we rename the method to
getLabelFieldTypesFromCaseFields() or sim? unless I'm misunderstanding what this is doing
we can just call caseDetails.getId(). We will never be searching on draft cases that are the ones with  no id
I can see this is duplicated in a couple of places. Can you add a method to the searchResultField class called getIdIncludingPath() or sim?
minor: NPE doesn't fit very well here? what about just a RuntimeException?
it would be good adding some explanatory comment here since it's not possible to deduct from the code why we are doing this.

I know it was like this already. But I don't think this method belongs here. The SearchQueryOperation should only concern with the actual execution of the external search. And be invoked only in that case. It's instead called before and after the actual search as well now which indicates it's doing too many unrelated things
perfect example of method than can be moved inside SearchResult itself

minor:
I've noticed that the "getSearchResultDefinition" is called multiple times, which will call this code multiple
times. Given that the performance of the search operation is important and this is potentially slow for big case types, we could consider refactoring to have it called only once if not a big change
any particular reason for adding the use case here? If not I'd suggest removing it
can you inline this method? i.e. remove it and call directly the CaseFieldPathUtils in the current invoker of this method
